newsitem.title: ESTONIA: BOURSE TO TRADE STOCK OPTIONS IN 1998.
newsitem.headline: BOURSE TO TRADE STOCK OPTIONS IN 1998.

text.p: The Tallinn stock exchange said on Monday that it had made a decision in principle to begin stock options trading in 1998.
"We discussed the issue (stock options trading) at the last board meeting on Friday and the answer was positive," Helo Meigas, managing director of the exchange, told Reuters.
"The answer was positive in the sense that we will eventually bring options trading to the bourse, but not before 1998," she added.
Meigas said that new regulations would be needed for options trading to begin on the bourse.
Hansapank, the only bank actively trading stock options, was happy with the move.
"If options were traded with stocks it would be very good and make it easier," Tonis Haavel, Hansapank's options trader, told Reuters.
Options trading in Estonia is still new.
Hansapank started trading options through a book system in November 1996. Hansapank offers options for up to six months.
Hoiupank has also expressed interest in trading in stock options and the two banks have held talks on using a compatible trading system.
